Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Berkeley Engineering RET plus Computing (BERET+C)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site at the University of California Berkeley seeks to strengthen K-12 education in the STEM disciplines by involving a total of a total of 27 science and mathematics teachers and 27 pre-service teachers from the Oakland and San Francisco Unified Schools Districts in an intensive eight-week summer engineering research experiences in computing and computational methods in engineering. The RET Site will involve a partnership between UC Berkeley faculty in engineering departments and centers as well as the UC Berkeley Cal Teach program in recruitment, program development, and implementation. The RET participants will gain first-hand multidisciplinary experiences to foster their development of the necessary pedagogical content knowledge to engage their own K-12 students in authentic experiences in science and engineering. The program will impact two areas that are of direct interest to the United States and the world: increasing access for K-12 teachers and their students to a deeper understanding of the STEM disciplines, research, and career opportunities; and inspiring teachers and students to pursue engineering careers.

Over a three-year period this RET Site will offer an intensive summer research program for a total of 54 K-12 STEM in-service and pre-service teachers in high needs school districts in Oakland and San Francisco. The multidisciplinary aspects of this research allows STEM teachers to strengthen their engineering design and computing knowledge and to incorporate their experiences into inquiry-based learning that will excite and interest their students. They will partner with the NSF Engineering Research Centers (ERCs) Nanomanfucturing Systems for Mobile computing and Mobile Energy Technologies (NASCENT) and Reinventing the Nation?s Urban Water Infrastructure (ReNUWIt) and other major research centers at UCB to leverage the faculty, resources, and infrastructure to support the RET Site program. Key features of the program include: 1) Direct supervision of projects and course material development by faculty mentors and graduate students; 2) Involvement of RET teachers and their students in timely, cutting-edge research projects in mobile computing and energy and urban water infrastructure that are translated into inquiry-based engineering curriculum enhancements; 3) Academic year engagement activities; and 4) Recruitment of STEM teachers from high needs school districts in the Oakland and San Francisco.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Berkeley Engineering Research Experiences for Teachers plus Computing (BERET+C) program engaged current and future K-12 science and math teachers in engineering and computational research to further develop California Bay area teachers’ understanding of scientific research, pedagogy and curriculum for guiding their K-12 students to practice engineering and computational research skills, and awareness of engineering and computer science degree options and careers. Teacher pairs made up of experienced math and science teachers and undergraduate science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors committed to becoming a teacher were placed in  multi-disciplinary research laboratories within many STEM departments at UC Berkeley. These included Departments of Bioengineering; Chemical Engineering; Electrical Engineering & Computer Science; Mechanical Engineering; Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology; Nuclear Engineering; and Physics; as well as the College of Natural Resources and the School of Information.


Over the four-year period of the award, a total of 64 summer research placements were made in which teachers conducted independent eight-week research projects in engineering research groups in which faculty mentors, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students were active, available, and involved. Teacher pairs used their summer research experiences as the basis for developing new lessons and curricular materials for K-12 classrooms that specifically highlight aspects of engineering and computational thinking.  During and after the summer research experience, teachers worked together to develop a total of 28 innovative hands-on engineering-based curricular units of several days to several weeks that they jointly taught in the K-12 classrooms during the academic year following the BERET+C summer. 


Other program activities included instructional and leadership opportunities for engineering graduate student mentors during implementation of BERET+C curriculum in K–12 classrooms, local engineering and computer science industry involvement through an Engineering Panel each summer in which industry representatives advised participants on future workforce needs, and extensive program evaluation and research providing insight into the impact of undergraduate and teacher research experiences. Studying impacts of the BERET+C program has led to specific research-based recommendations for designers of Research Experiences for Teachers programs at other organizations and universities. They have also provided insight into what undergraduates and teachers learn from research experiences as well as what their gaps are in understanding their research projects, as well as how undergraduates later take what they learn into their classrooms after they become teachers. Such research findings have helped faculty research mentors and undergraduate and teacher research programs improve what these experiences offer to future participants. 


A number of conference presentations to STEM teacher educators at national conferences, as well as two peer-reviewed publications, have resulted from BERET+C program activities. These include a literature review of teacher research experiences, and a research study that investigated learning outcomes of undergraduate and teacher research experiences. Additional manuscripts for peer-reviewed science education journals are in preparation.
